commit_message:
Fix logic error

if security_sshd_permit_root_login is not set to yes, we should
override this and template a "no", instead of templating a "no"
when the value is set to yes.

 Conflicts:
	templates/sshd_config_block.j2

Change-Id: I747a8818762119eee63fa03d175b66ae4021f6da
Closes-Bug: #1685194
(cherry picked from commit 2cf232ae627514bccc283ef3f578e422f7bcf745)

the ports pool functionality is enabled. This ensures the
controller pod is not set to ready until all the precreated ports
have been loaded into their respective pools. This helps admins
to know when the kuryr-controller pod is prepared to start serving
requests.

Note the kuryr-controller will reply to request even if it is not
on ready status. However, that will lead to trigger port creation
for new pods as the already existing ports may not be on their
respective pools yet.

Change-Id: Id47d3e7450551c19cb19d9278e459bd32bf364cf
'}]
commit_message:
Add readiness probe to kuryr-controller pod

This patch add a readiness probe to the kuryr controller when
the ports pool functionality is enabled. This ensures the
controller pod is not set to ready until all the precreated ports
have been loaded into their respective pools. This helps admins
to know when the kuryr-controller pod is prepared to start serving
requests.

Note the kuryr-controller will reply to request even if it is not
on ready status. However, that will lead to trigger port creation
for new pods as the already existing ports may not be on their
respective pools yet.

Change-Id: Id47d3e7450551c19cb19d9278e459bd32bf364cf

per the comment in the bug, this should be left to the operator to decide whether they want to perform this operation or not.

This is currently the ONLY way to safely reduce the size of the storage volume on a database and as such this is more of a feature than a bug.

The issue here is more that the bug list is old and needs scrubbing, and new contributors who wish to contribute are going to fall victim to old and meaningless bugs.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-08-14 19:01:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

commit_message:
Add volume size verify for replica based on master

According bug description, replica should has volume size at least
as much as the master. Otherwise it maybe cause exception for
replica data. To solve this problem,I added judgement for volume
size when create a replica, which not smaller than master
volume size. And make this function as configurable by
CONF.verify_replica_volume_size.
Also provide a test case to validate the method.

Change-Id: I5e110ce672c1b1715bca1727d70d656301cd0d43
Closes-Bug: #1357500

if security_sshd_permit_root_login is not set to yes, we should
override this and template a "no", instead of templating a "no"

Change-Id: I747a8818762119eee63fa03d175b66ae4021f6da
Closes-Bug: #1685194
(cherry picked from commit 2cf232ae627514bccc283ef3f578e422f7bcf745)

commit_message:
Fix logic error

if security_sshd_permit_root_login is not set to yes, we should
override this and template a "no", instead of templating a "no"
when the value is set to yes.

Change-Id: I747a8818762119eee63fa03d175b66ae4021f6da
Closes-Bug: #1685194
(cherry picked from commit 2cf232ae627514bccc283ef3f578e422f7bcf745)

subject: Remove superfluous role_name arguments
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-13 12:39:49.000000000', 'message': "Remove superfluous role_name arguments

This patch removes the role_name when using openstack_user's :create
action (it gets ignored by the target method).

Note that the spec test would still pass if only the line in
identity_registration.rb (but not the test) were changed, because the
code that actually does grant the role to the resource is executed right
after user creation and before any tests check the resource for the
existence of the role_name attribute. In other words: if the argument
were required in a call but only supplied in another call, the spec
tests would not catch it. Something to watch out for.

Change-Id: Ic45dd42453d9f8ae2a8c4d04f830cff67740cac6
"}]
commit_message:
Remove superfluous role_name arguments

This patch removes the role_name when using openstack_user's :create
action (it gets ignored by the target method).

Note that the spec test would still pass if only the line in
identity_registration.rb (but not the test) were changed, because the
code that actually does grant the role to the resource is executed right
after user creation and before any tests check the resource for the
existence of the role_name attribute. In other words: if the argument
were required in a call but only supplied in another call, the spec
tests would not catch it. Something to watch out for.

Change-Id: Ic45dd42453d9f8ae2a8c4d04f830cff67740cac6

commit_message:
Refactor to use p-o-i classes for Beaker

To make things more consistent, we'll rely on the integration
classes to centralize units.

commit_message:
Support services in different namespaces

Pass the service namespace to kubernetes-entrypoint in
order to support dependencies between namespaces.
Add documentation about endpoint/service namespaces.

Change-Id: I208c3240e9f2c8900323595f7b0e488bef5cb1fc
Implements: blueprint entrypoint-namespaces

messages:
[{'account_id': 22818, 'date': '2017-10-31 22:34:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2017-10-31 22:34:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-11-07 00:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

If the route targets, import targets or export targets are empty in the
django form, the creation or modification of the bgpvpn failed.
The neutron server return a error (Invalid input for export_targets.
Reason: '' is not a valid input.)
The route_targets are not correctly formatted and a empty string is sent
instead an empty list when the fields route_targets are empty in the form.

Change-Id: I3b233f68c12795713daf6c1a00042730eea84c56
Closes-Bug: 1730678

commit_message:
dashboard: impossible to add a bgpvpn with a empty route target

If the route targets, import targets or export targets are empty in the
django form, the creation or modification of the bgpvpn failed.
The neutron server return a error (Invalid input for export_targets.
Reason: '' is not a valid input.)
The route_targets are not correctly formatted and a empty string is sent
instead an empty list when the fields route_targets are empty in the form.

Change-Id: I3b233f68c12795713daf6c1a00042730eea84c56
Closes-Bug: 1730678

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-09-14 20:09:08.000000000', 'message': "Tempest tests to check L3 BGPVPN RTs update

Added complex tempest tests that verify update of L3 BGPVPN route
targets in different conditions
- Change of RT to iRT<>eRT and again to only RT
- Change of RT to, RT with iRT<>eRT and again only RT
- Change of eRT<>iRT to RT with sequentional network association

Tests should check that update doesn't break connectivity when route
targets are defined properly and in opposite, when route targets
don't assure proper connectivity - it shouldn't be possible

Change-Id: Ice15324e704048945e4371f4a7eb2e24744fefd7

commit_message:
Tempest tests to check L3 BGPVPN RTs update

Added complex tempest tests that verify update of L3 BGPVPN route
targets in different conditions
- Change of RT to iRT<>eRT and again to only RT
- Change of RT to, RT with iRT<>eRT and again only RT
- Change of eRT<>iRT to RT with sequentional network association

Tests should check that update doesn't break connectivity when route
targets are defined properly and in opposite, when route targets
don't assure proper connectivity - it shouldn't be possible

Related-Bug: 1716893
Related-Bug: 1719822
Depends-On: Ia69e63d5e60ab539c40a2de373b5ffe4b46548f8
Change-Id: Ice15324e704048945e4371f4a7eb2e24744fefd7

commit_message:
Fix filesystem permission masks

The setuid bit is ignored on directories, so it's not necessary
to remove it. The tasks currently remove the user's ability to
use their home directory.

The patch fixes the permissions problem, ensures that the 'nobody'
user is skipped, and enables testing for the tasks in the gate.

Closes-Bug: 1731005
Closes-Bug: 1730994
Change-Id: Id7be77b2eaa707c4c27d46f97d07f34825813749
(cherry picked from commit 79b3d25070f86804bd6cc4b04a82f2a9bb1f4982)

I mostly agree with the proposal (I think the policy name is going to be changed, so that fixes one of my nits). One comment inline about the Phase I length.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-10-16 12:36:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2799, 'date': '2017-10-16 12:38:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-10-16 14:07:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes I think we should consider there is one and only one stable branch policy, with two set of rules depending on whether you are a classic project or a deployment/lifecycle project. That way they can both use the same tag (follows-stable-policy).'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-10-16 22:09:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2017-10-17 01:46:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Leaving the bikeshedding around the name aside I think this is just going to be confusing, no matter how it would be extended.

I'd personally prefer not claiming the projects like lifecycle management/ installers/ etc. stable tag at all if the trailing release is not enough. Rather just release even on the same time as the rest, backport what you need and don't assert the tag.

IIRC the trailing release was to address this specific problem where project is depending latest and the greatest of some other project to release (consistently like installer enabling deployment of the feature). I recall seeing earlier discussion (not so long ago) about this already pointing out that maybe the stable tag is not right for such projects.

I'd like to understand what's the driving force to have such tag? If you clearly need to bring backported features (such as the vendor driver support), why would you _need_ to try to claim stable tag? If you need to consistently break the rules being the reason in business, technical or social reasons, don't assert the tag and live with it. Already in the comments it seems like the timeline is quite flexible depending whom you ask and I can only see that pressure increasing if there is "relaxed" policy, which is even easier to justify exceptions.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-10-17 09:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Still trying to wrap my head around this. At the core of this discussion is: what is a deployment/lifecycle management solution and what should "stable" mean in this context ?

Is "stable" really what users want from a good and mature deployment/lifecycle management solution ? Should they really all strive to follow something close to the upstream stable-policy, and be about reducing behavior changes and feature additions ?

To me a user-friendly deployment/lifecycle framework is one that I could use continuously without breaking, whether I want to stay on a given branch (and therefore not get any new version, but potentially get the late features associated with that version), or upgrade to new branches and get new features.

I'm starting to wonder if "stable" is the best paradigm to express the desirable state here, and whether we should not shoot for something else...'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-10-17 14:30:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-10-17 14:32:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Leaving the bikeshedding around the name aside I think this is just
 > going to be confusing, no matter how it would be extended.
 > 
 > I'd personally prefer not claiming the projects like lifecycle
 > management/ installers/ etc. stable tag at all if the trailing
 > release is not enough. Rather just release even on the same time as
 > the rest, backport what you need and don't assert the tag.

That is already an option, but the projects see value in having a tag that expresses some level of maturity in the project.

 > IIRC the trailing release was to address this specific problem
 > where project is depending latest and the greatest of some other
 > project to release (consistently like installer enabling deployment
 > of the feature). I recall seeing earlier discussion (not so long
 > ago) about this already pointing out that maybe the stable tag is
 > not right for such projects.

The current definition of the trailing release model and stable tags don't allow for backports to allow old versions of deployment tools to support new hardware with old versions of OpenStack."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2017-10-17 16:32:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> IIRC the trailing release was to address this specific problem where project is depending latest and the greatest of some other project to release (consistently like installer enabling deployment of the feature). I recall seeing earlier discussion (not so long ago) about this already pointing out that maybe the stable tag is not right for such projects.

I personally don't think the small timeframe given to the trailing release projects is not sufficient to cover the problems we're trying to address with this tag. Otherwise the trailing release should be given +6months instead of +2weeks from upstream final release.  I think this is related to the feedback cycle required to actually hear from consumers as it relates to their usage of a given version.

> I'd like to understand what's the driving force to have such tag? If you clearly need to bring backported features (such as the vendor driver support), why would you _need_ to try to claim stable tag? If you need to consistently break the rules being the reason in business, technical or social reasons, don't assert the tag and live with it. Already in the comments it seems like the timeline is quite flexible depending whom you ask and I can only see that pressure increasing if there is "relaxed" policy, which is even easier to justify exceptions.

So the desire is to be able to define and express some stricter policy  than not having the stable-policy while still having the flexibility to do the necessary work so that operators/deployers can actually consume the output.  The current stable-policy runs into issues with deployment projects because it's more targeted to established API single service and doesn't take in to account the needs of deployment tools which may not be able to continue to function with such hard requirements.  Deployment tools need to be flexiable enough to adjust to the needs of their users after the final release for a given version as feedback is given for issues being raised once their end users are able to consume it.

IMHO the feedback flow for the various groups occurs as folks start consuming the outputs of the previous group. Deployment tools feed into the upstream projects during the cycle as we attempt to consume the new features that are being written. The deployers don't start providing feedback until after the initial release so we don't get actual bugs from our end users until after the release.  And operators/end users start feeding back to the upstream projects after they get their clouds deployed.  And user's may not be able to wait until the next cycle for solutions because that means waiting for a new set of issues related to newer versions of OpenStack.  When an end user settles on a specific version of OpenStack to deploy X (for whatever their reasons), they aren't looking to wait another 6 months and getting X+1 or X+2.

For things like vendor integration this falls in an odd time frame related to larger enterprises like to consume more "stable" versions and the length of time required to actually prove out these integrations.  I know from the TripleO front we push them to do it in master first but need to be able to backport it to the versions that the comsumer actually wants to deploy. We do support deploying N-1 with the current version but sometimes end users are still wanting N-2 so we need that flexibility.  That doesn't mean we want to allow the backport of everything but we would like the option to while still expressing a framework policy to do so.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2017-10-17 20:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Oops added an extra not in my previous comment. It should read

"I personally think the small timeframe given to the trailing release projects is not sufficient to cover the problems we're trying to address with this tag."'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-10-18 08:06:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Still thinking out loud...

A release is really a point in time when you signal to users that they can start using the thing with limited risk of getting broken. The stable policy is an artifact around it, describing the types of changes that are acceptable post-release.

If two weeks is not enough to produce a "release" that lets you switch to a different patch-acceptance policy, maybe the simpler would be to extend that cycle-trailing period to whatever is necessary.

Otherwise it feels like we are creating two points in time (two releases): one mostly-there-may-be-missing-a-few-upstream-features one two weeks after the main release, and one this-time-all-the-features-are-there a couple of months after. In OpenStack-speak the first one is really a beta or a RC while the second one is the real release.

So an alternative to describing a relaxed stable policy would be to extend the cycle-trailing period to whatever is needed to catch up. With the work around the OpenStack map now clearly identifying which projects are in the "deployment/lifecycle management" bucket, it is imho doable to have a more significantly different release policy for this specific bucket.

That is what most integrators do anyway (trail the release) and limiting the options of the ones that are openly developed in our community may put them at a disadvantage.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-10-24 21:41:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I see a lot of great ideas and good feedback - I'm wondering if we could wait Sydney and discuss in person about this topic."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-10-25 13:35:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sounds like a good topic to discuss more directly, yes. Do we have a session we can reuse or should we ask for one of the "extra" last-minute session slot ?'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2017-10-26 06:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2017-10-26 06:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Sounds like a good topic to discuss more directly, yes. Do we have
 > a session we can reuse or should we ask for one of the "extra"
 > last-minute session slot ?

Yup https://www.openstack.org/summit/sydney-2017/summit-schedule/events/20456/what-do-operators-want-from-the-stable-policy'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2017-10-26 06:35:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Still thinking out loud...
 > 
 > A release is really a point in time when you signal to users that
 > they can start using the thing with limited risk of getting broken.
 > The stable policy is an artifact around it, describing the types of
 > changes that are acceptable post-release.
 > 
 > If two weeks is not enough to produce a "release" that lets you
 > switch to a different patch-acceptance policy, maybe the simpler
 > would be to extend that cycle-trailing period to whatever is
 > necessary.

I feel like that would help but it makes other things difficult.  Say we upped the gap from 2w to 3m that dilutes the message around what OpenStack $Release is and I expect it makes companies building products on this work later, so they'd be releasing $Product much later after $Release was made.
 
 > Otherwise it feels like we are creating two points in time (two
 > releases): one mostly-there-may-be-missing-a-few-upstream-features
 > one two weeks after the main release, and one this-time-all-the-features-are-there
 > a couple of months after. In OpenStack-speak the first one is
 > really a beta or a RC while the second one is the real release.

Yup that was similar to my first impression, I've 'mellowed' a little on that but it still feels like we're at some level moving certain projects from a 6 month  to a 9 month (overlapping) development cycle.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2017-10-30 16:58:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I feel like that would help but it makes other things difficult.  Say we upped the gap from 2w to 3m that dilutes the message around what OpenStack $Release is and I expect it makes companies building products on this work later, so they'd be releasing $Product much later after $Release was made.


So this is where I think from an end user perspective the dev/operator thing is blurred. It may be the date release but if no one can consume it (because tooling isn't there or is incomplete), is it something that should have been released/consumed?  For the core projects themselves they bundle all the bits up and date release it. From there the deployment tools need to react to the items released so that operators can deploy it.  Maybe the deployment tools need to not be part of the OpenStack $Release and need to follow more of the Tempest versioning policy where X.0.0 = OpenStack $Release.  I think this is unfortunate because it seems to not take the operator in to consideration under the larger OpenStack umbrella when we "release" something'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-11-14 15:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

The community discussed about this topic during the OpenStack Summit in Sydney:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/SYD-stable-policy

And we decided that stable-policy tag should be dropped for deployment projects and make sure the software catalog is adapted to not show it as missing.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-13 21:48:40.000000000', 'message': 'stable-maint: add stable-policy-relax policy

This adds a new policy, called "stable-policy-relax" which has similar
time frames as stable-policy but different supported changes.

Indeed, some projects (installers) are developing features that are
sometimes depending on other projects in OpenStack.
Example:
Neutron now supports OVN backends and complex DPDK environments.
Installers have to create automation recipes to deploy these new
environments but can't really do it before the feature is actually
finished (otherwise it can't be tested remember). That said, it makes
sense to give an extra-time (Phase I) for them to implement what's
called "Features" in installers, after a stable release.
The phases criteria are documented in the patch.

The intent isn't to let installers backporting everything or anything
but rather understand their use-cases and problems, and give to them
some extra time so they can deliver stronger tools available to our
operators and providing nice features for our end users; so we can
continue to be competitive etc.

A patch will be proposed in Governance to create stable-policy-relax tag
and explain (again) why we're doing this.

Change-Id: I390436eef5bc18f39432cccbd5d800ad92fb5c3e
'}]
commit_message:
stable-maint: add stable-policy-relax policy

This adds a new policy, called "stable-policy-relax" which has similar
time frames as stable-policy but different supported changes.

Indeed, some projects (installers) are developing features that are
sometimes depending on other projects in OpenStack.
Example:
Neutron now supports OVN backends and complex DPDK environments.
Installers have to create automation recipes to deploy these new
environments but can't really do it before the feature is actually
finished (otherwise it can't be tested remember). That said, it makes
sense to give an extra-time (Phase I) for them to implement what's
called "Features" in installers, after a stable release.
The phases criteria are documented in the patch.

The intent isn't to let installers backporting everything or anything
but rather understand their use-cases and problems, and give to them
some extra time so they can deliver stronger tools available to our
operators and providing nice features for our end users; so we can
continue to be competitive etc.

A patch will be proposed in Governance to create stable-policy-relax tag
and explain (again) why we're doing this.

Change-Id: I390436eef5bc18f39432cccbd5d800ad92fb5c3e

commit_message:
Fix leak of password info in logs.

When launching a database instance, user info is logged at info
level.  This user info includes password information that should
not appear in the logs.  This fix removes logging of user info.

Change-Id: I97206a3fe0c19ee7cb7333ed27518134079f26d0

commit_message:
Tempest utility functions modified

Modifications of function for complex tests:
- more than 2 servers can be created
- more than 2 networks can be created
- more than one subnet in each network is possible
- subnets of the same CIDR are possible
- more than one L3 BGPVPN can be created
- L3 BGPVPN can be deleted in test
- tests between different servers are possible
- indexing of variables changed to keys for better
  readability
- port 80/http added to security group
- function to setup http name server added
- extracted function to setup ssh client
- extracted function to associate floating ip
- L3 BGPVPN check function optionally checks name of the
  destination server - is it the same as expexted
- L3 BGPVPN check function makes clear of ARP entry
  after first unsuccessful ping sequence

Change-Id: I2302a92e7228eaf5ddf1cafc13e30b97b224fcb0

gcc so use that instead.

commit_message:
add safe_clone_repo function

We have logic for dealing with cloning errors repeated in several
places. This patch combines it into one function that can be called
more easily without having to trap exceptions.

Change-Id: Ib5f6c3f801481b28513ce8fab0f5624c02e60d97
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

'}, {'created': '2017-11-09 19:15:18.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Introduce hpOneView and ilorest to OneView"

Reverting these changes because python-hpOneView does not provide HTTPS
secure connection with custom CAcert and could cause a possible security issue.

This reverts commit 3a5288a9adcb184ac4cc371816dc2ffa18695bbb.

Change-Id: I04d8435627873380bced7dc31f7469cdeb4bed12
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Introduce hpOneView and ilorest to OneView"

Reverting these changes because python-hpOneView does not provide HTTPS
secure connection with custom CAcert and could cause a possible security issue.

This reverts commit 3a5288a9adcb184ac4cc371816dc2ffa18695bbb.

Change-Id: I04d8435627873380bced7dc31f7469cdeb4bed12

commit_message:
do not look for .gitreview for existing releases

Look for a .gitreview file for new releases and for branches.

Change-Id: Ic4a889a945fff5d8ce4d73d1c9f7097726d572f7
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Handle InstanceNotFound when setting password via metadata

When setting an instance password via the metadata service, if the
instance is not found it results in a 500 response to the caller.

This change handles the InstanceNotFound error and returns it as
a 400. Note it's a 400 since the instance uuid is part of the POST
request body, not on the URL path so it's not a 404 response.

Change-Id: I4aa99b563e1a5a87aa3e3dfb28800f107676df92
Partial-Bug: #1696848

commit_message:
Add shade-functional-tips jobs

shade provides a project-template to run its functional tests against
tips of key libraries, such as os-client-config and keystoneauth.

Add these to os-client-config so we can ensure we don't break anything.

Change-Id: I9619fc09ca7c0f6fd3021d3b5194131ad172ad16
Depends-On: I544fdf515f8df38d73cee64a6de799ab384a326e

commit_message:
Pass the CloudDomain parameter down to hiera on all nodes

We currently do not have a single hiera key that simply
returns the CloudDomain (Domain Suffix) that was configured
during the deployment. As it is a rather useful thing to have
on the overcloud nodes, let's pass it down for all roles.

IHA is at least one user where this information is needed in
hiera.

Change-Id: I7a510e3bbeb367a46bf6ccc565393b1e7a1a1f33

'}, {'created': '2017-08-02 13:48:44.000000000', 'message': 'Vault based key manager

* Uses https://www.vaultproject.io/ to store/fetch secrets.
* All we need is the URL and the Token to talk to the vault server.
* tox target "functional-vault" sets up a server in development mode
  and runs functional tests
* Supports both http:// and https:// url(s)
* the https support was tested by setting up a vault server by hand
  (https://gist.github.com/dims/47674cf2c3b0a953df69246c2ea1ff78)
* create_key_pair is the only API that is not implemented

commit_message:
Vault based key manager

* Uses https://www.vaultproject.io/ to store/fetch secrets
* All we need is the URL and a Token to talk to the vault server
* tox target "functional-vault" sets up a server in development mode
  and runs functional tests
* Supports both http:// and https:// url(s)
* the https support was tested by setting up a vault server by hand
  (https://gist.github.com/dims/47674cf2c3b0a953df69246c2ea1ff78)
* create_key_pair is the only API that is not implemented

Change-Id: I6436e5841c8e77a7262b4d5aa39201b40a985255

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it. People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch and resubmit a new change-set. Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base. Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you. commit_message:
Use specified phrases in lieu of 'Used' for limit summary

Some resources, namely floating IPs, are limited based on those
allocated, rather than in actual use. The "Allocated" string is present
in the code but not used in the template. This effectively changes "Used
X of Y" to "Allocated X of Y" for floating IPs.

Change-Id: I7919b883a47d66b1e870862363d07e0f90bdbe7b
Closes-Bug: #1708733

subject: update_network should consider qos if or not name of network changes

[{'account_id': 21550, 'date': '2017-11-09 03:32:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2017-11-09 08:39:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

If this patch is addressing a bug for QoS, then I think it should be better clarified in commit message. Also do we want to update the network in all cases? For example, what would buy us calling update_network if some other parameter change (f.e. mtu?). Looks like we need to fix something for QoS so I'd suggest to open a bug in launchpad with the details. This way we can backport it to stable branches as well.
Thanks!
Daniel"}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2017-11-09 08:40:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Some test would be great which checks the code path that you are actually trying to fix.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2017-11-09 14:22:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

Thanks for the patch,

I agree this check is redundant since it's already being checked in OVNClient. The QOS driver also seems to be doing the right thing and discarding the update in case nothing has changed.

So LGTM"}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2017-11-09 15:36:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
update_network should consider qos if or not name of network changes

update_network in ovn_client has the judgment of whether the name
of the network changes, update network should consider qos, so
delete the judgment in mech_driver.

Change-Id: Id98072daa82cbdeb27a8675a2250d73dfb5d2977
